awd_titl_txt: Trans-disciplinary Education in Biology and Engineering Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on increasing diversity in STEM and increasing student and teacher experiences and competency in the fields of biology and engineering. An integrated education program at the intersection of biology and engineering - the sensory guidance of behavior in biological organisms and autonomous robots - will be developed and studied. The project will consist of: (a) an integrated three-week summer program for rising 12th-grade students and in-service secondary education teachers; (b) a college credit course and workshops for students during their 12th grade school year, and; (c) paid summer internships upon graduation. In these programs, students will engage in hands-on biological investigations to learn how animals sense and respond to their environments. They will then integrate scientific principles with authentic engineering technology to build and program robots based on animals. The robots will be equipped with sensors and behaviors and execute tasks designed by the students. Subsequent internships will serve to further connect student knowledge of integrated biology and engineering with real-world experiences. Creating this program under the framework of animal/robot sensorimotor systems is particularly timely since biology and robotics are producing exciting, emerging technologies and are major growth industries. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

The research seeks to (1) increase awareness and participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields; (2) increase interest, attitudes, knowledge, and self-efficacy in biology, engineering, and technology fields and occupations, and; (3) develop a model to educate students and to train teachers in concepts that examine the interrelatedness between science and engineering. The project's formative and summative evaluation methods, including surveys, focus groups, and open-ended evaluations of workshop and internship experiences, will be used to study these issues. The research will contribute new insights into integrated STEM curricula and how they support students in developing and sustaining interests in learning and working in scientific fields. The project also engages underrepresented youth in critical thinking, problem-solving, and real-world investigations in biology and engineering that may lead them to pursue STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project created authentic, transdisciplinary learning experiences at the intersection of sensory biology, robotics, and computer programming, with an overarching goal of increasing diversity in STEM and increasing student and teacher experiences in the fields of biology and engineering. The purpose of this project was to (1) increase awareness and participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields; (2) improve student interest, attitudes, knowledge, and self-efficacy in biology, engineering, and technology fields and occupations; (3) assess how students develop their problem-solving skills and knowledge with respect to tasks at the interface of biology and engineering. and; (4) develop a model to educate students and to train teachers in concepts that examine the interrelatedness between science and engineering.

 

The program directly impacted local students in primarily urban high schools by creating an educational model that prepared students to enter into the modern STEM workforce. The project developed transdisciplinary content and introduced that content over multiple years to students through a summer program and a university course that could be taken for college credit. Workforce development was also provided through paid student summer internships. The program also trained teachers to support students in transdisciplinary thinking and learning through teacher professional development workshops and the introduction of curriculum into the high school classroom.

 

Tangible products of this project include a set of five curriculum modules that introduce students to the foundations of robotics programming, to the basic principles of sensory behavior, and to investigations and applications of sensory guided behaviors, including sonar, vision, and sound-guided behavior. Each of these modules includes attention to biology, engineering, and the intersections of the two, and they include open-ended problem-solving tasks for students to apply knowledge and skills from multiple disciplines. The curriculum modules also include instructional guides to help high school teachers translate the content into high school classes.

 

Project outcomes have further been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at conferences, and a dedicated website, and major outcomes are outlined below. Student learning was assessed through surveys and observations of their work during the summer program, the university course, and the internship experiences. Several sets of findings emerged from this work. Students who participated in the transdisciplinary curriculum through the university course or in their high school class showed a statistically significant increase in science and, respectively, engineering-related interest. These findings indicate that students improved their general interest in STEM careers, their potential to learn STEM, and their perceived usefulness of STEM disciplines. Additionally, we found that students who completed the curriculum in their high school class showed increases in their interests and self-efficacy. This outcome may be attributable to the respective populations of students, as students who opted in to the university course began the program with higher interest and self-efficacy. This has important implications for future research, as it suggests we can reach a wider range of students by integrating the biology-engineering curriculum into high school settings.

 

The necessary shift to remote learning during this project led to findings on how to support student learning and collaboration in remote and hybrid settings requiring the use of physical equipment such as robots. Although students could not take robots home with them, they could use remote desktop software to log in from their home computers to a computer on campus that was connected to their robot. Students working in pairs or groups were able to alternate who came to campus and collaborate through video calls during scheduled class time. This design allowed students to maintain autonomy in their work and contributed positively to student self-efficacy in collaboration and problem-solving (DeJarnette et al., 2024).

 

Qualitative analyses indicated that students developed not only content knowledge, but also science and engineering skills and practices, through their participation in the transdisciplinary curriculum. From student work on biology and engineering lab assignments, we documented evidence of computational problem-solving skills, systems thinking, and data practices (DeJarnette et al., 2022). Students developed collaborative learning and argumentation skills - such as posing questions and providing justifications for claims - because labs were designed to require input from each person within a group (DeJarnette et al., 2023).
